description.narrative:
Persons with disability are considered one of the most marginalized sectors in society because of discrimination and lack of opportunity for employment. Many have no source of income or livelihood and are fully dependent to their families. Many are stillbegging in the streets for daily living. This proposed projects seeks support for the following: 1.) equals.org.ph management and trainings for persons with disability users, 2.) Social media marketing of the website, 3) linkaging with other support providers for persons with disability
It is the aim of the project to benefit hundreds of persons with disability that will register in the website looking for a job. Persons with disability will also benefit by getting information through the websites about the various resources available for them.
The proposed project will ensure involvement of persons with disability in all stages of the project. Persons with disability are not only end-user of the project but the management of the website is being done by persons with disability themselves.
The equals.org.ph hopes to provide these avenues and to disseminate information on the various resources available for persons with disability. The website was created but there are no funds that would maintain and propel the achievement of its objectives.

participating-org.narrative: Philippine Council of Organization Disability Empowerment

Philippine Council of Organization on Disability and Empowerment Inc. ( PHILCODE) formerly the Philippine Council of Cheshire Homesfor the Disabled ( PHILCOCHED) is an umbrella organization of organizations legally registered in the Philippines, either as associations or foundations with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) or as primary cooperatives with the Cooperative Development Authority. Its members organizations offer programs and services to persons with disabilities such as Residential Homes, Livelihood Activities, Medical Assistance, Formal and Non-Formal Education and those that promote the inclusion of persons with disabilities in mainstream employment. The history and thrusts The Cheshire Home movement in the Philippines started with the birth of the #Sinagtala# meaning #Star of Hope# Cheshire Home in 1965. The idea was introduced by Mr. Patrick Monford, a young Oxford graduate whose father was then Charge de# Affairs of the Phil British Embassy. With the help of 2 Filipino U.K. Colombo scholars, he together with a group of civic-spirited people organized the first Board of Directors of the Home. The Philippine Council of Homes for the Disabled (PhilCOHOD), Inc. was, therefore, established. 6 By 1990, it had 25 Cheshire Homes located in Metro Manila, and provinces like Benguet (Baguio City), Capiz (Ibisan), Cavite (Alfonso), Iloilo (Sta. Barbara), Ilocos Sur (Vigan), La Union (Agoo), Zamboanga (Pagadian), to name a few. The rise of the Cheshire movement was significantly led and supported by the religious sisters from the ICM congregation , in the person of, Sr. Valeriana Baerts, Sr. Maria Gielkens, Sr. Teresita Aranda, and Sr. Roos Catry. Together with the National Orthopedic Hospital Chief, Dr. Benjamin Tamesis, they and highly civic-spirited individuals established the different homes for the disabled. In 2000, (PHILCOHOD), Inc. was renamed to Philippine Council of Cheshire Home for the Disabled (PhilCOCHED). It servedas the umbrella organization of all the Cheshire Homes. At that time, it was a non-stock, private, charitable organization, composed of representative officials from organized Cheshire Homes dedicated to the welfare of the incurably sick, abandoned disabled and handicapped. In 2006, Leonard Cheshire Disability ofU.K. actively participated in the operations of PHILCOCHED by introducing and funding mass-based projects for the disabled in the Philippines a) Inclusive Education, b) Economic Empowerment and c) Young Voices. The projects were under the wings of PhilCOCHED for almost 5 years until 2010. Need for a Council of Organizations In February 2011, Sr. Valeriana Baerts, I.C.M., one of the founders of the Cheshire Home Movement in the Philippines, formed a Technical Committee to review the organization and articles of incorporation of the PhilCOCHED in order to keep pace with the changing needs of the clientele of PhilCOCHED. For the last three decades, the Council was composed of individual #Homes or Bahay# which were under the direct supervision of organizations devoted to the disabled, particularly, the orthopedically challenged. The residents of the #Homes# needed more than residential facilities. Livelihood, medical, education and other support services were likewise important to have a betterquality of life. A Council composed of different organizations devoted to persons with disabilities whose thrusts are focused on the aforementioned areas could work together and be more equipped to answer the myriad needs of pwds, those in the #Homes# as well as the members of these organizations.
